note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.

M. D. Haynes was a public official in Mississippi before and during the Civil War.

An active member of the Democratic Party in the 1840s and 1850s, Haynes worked as an editor of the Mississippian, a newspaper in Jackson, before seeking the office of State Treasurer in 1859. He won the position and served in that role through the Civil War. Haynes tried very hard to keep Mississippi’s finances in order through the war years, but faced significant hardships due to the strain of war and from Union army campaigns. He moved the treasury office from Jackson to Meridian in May 1863 to avoid Union troops under William Tecumseh Sherman, and then to Mobile, Alabama, for fear of Union cavalry raids.

In late 1864, as the Confederacy was falling apart, an audit of Mississippi’s state funds discovered a substantial discrepancy, and officials accused Haynes of owing the state more than $93,000. Governor Charles Clark demanded Haynes’ resignation based upon assumptions that the treasurer had stolen or embezzled the money. On January 2, 1865, Haynes resigned from his position as State Treasurer and committed suicide the same day. Adding to this tragedy was news from a later examination that found Haynes was innocent of the charges. The money shortfall had been the fault of a previous treasurer. Long after his death, Mississippi officials occasionally referenced Haynes’ untimely death, positing that his well-known and frequent use of opium may have contributed to his suicide.

(Semi-Weekly Mississippian, Jackson, MS, July 8, 1859; Natchez Democrat, Natchez, MS, November 29, 1865; Timothy B. Smith, Mississippi in the Civil War: The Home Front, 92, 98; Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, July 25, 1894)

Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)

Located in Warren County, Mississippi, Vicksburg was founded under the name Fort Nogales as early as 1790 in what was then unincorporated territory. In 1798, upon creation of Mississippi Territory, it was renamed Walnut Hills. On April 1, 1799, Walnut Hills became part of the newly created Pickering County (later renamed Jefferson County on January 10, 1802), until the creation of Claiborne County on January 26, 1802. It then became part of its current county of Warren on December 21, 1809. Upon its incorporation on January 29th, 1825, it was renamed Vicksburg. Vicksburg became the county seat in 1836 and remains today. (Rowland, Mississippi, 858; Wikipedia; Britannica; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: The act of beginning to fight or a period of time in a war, military engagements are also referred to as battles or skirmishes. Battles are fights between armed forces, and usually describe singular events that occur over the course of hours or a few days. Skirmishes are smaller fights, usually between a small number of soldiers that occur unexpectedly, last only a few minutes or a few hours, and take place away from the main area of fighting.

There were approximately 10,500 engagements during the American Civil War. Fifty of them were major battles, while another one hundred were notable engagements. The rest were small battles or skirmishes. (Cambridge Dictionary; American Battlefield Trust)

The Second Battle of Corinth was fought on October 3 – 4, 1862 at the town of Corinth, Alcorn County, Mississippi between the Army of the Mississippi (Union) commanded by Maj. Gen. William Rosecrans and the Army of West Tennessee (Confederate) commanded by Maj. Gen. Earl Van Dorn and resulted in a Union victory. Maj. Gen. Sterling Price marched his army to meet up with Van Dorn for the purpose of attacking Corinth to disrupt Union lines of communication and then march into middle Tennessee. Union forces repelled the attack and on October 4, 1862, Van Dorn withdrew his army towards Tennessee and then into Mississippi. The total number of forces engaged was 45,000; 23,000 Union and 22,000 Confederate. Casualties from the battle were estimated at 7,197 with 2,359 Union and 4,838 Confederate. (American Battlefield Trust; Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Military Engagements--Mill Springs, Battle of, Ky., 1862

gloss.p: The Battle of Mill Springs (also known as the Battle of Logan’s Crossroads and the Battle of Fishing Creek) was fought on January 19, 1862 in Pulaski and Wayne counties, Kentucky between Union forces commanded by Brig. Gen. George H. Thomas and Confederate forces commanded by Maj. Gen. George B. Crittenden and resulted in a Union victory. In November of 1861, the commander of Crittenden’s first brigade, Brig. Gen Felix K. Zollicoffer, moved his force across the Cumberland River into west Kentucky and set up his winter headquarters in Mill Springs. Thomas arrived at Logan’s Crossroads on January 17 with orders to break up the Confederate forces under Crittenden and drive them across the Cumberland River. On the morning of January 19, Zollicoffer’s brigade attacked Thomas’ position at Logan’s Crossroads. Crittenden moved the rest of his forces from Knoxville, Tennessee to reinforce Zollicoffer. Thomas’ forces repeated attacks on their position. Zollicoffer was killed in the fighting. Reinforcements under Brig. General. Albin F. Schoepf arrived from Somerset, Kentucky and attacked the Confederates, causing them to break and retreat. That night, Crittenden moved his forces across the Cumberland River into Tennessee. The total number of forces engaged in the battle was 10,300; 4,400 Union and 5,900 Confederate. Casualties from the battle were estimated at 814 with 262 Union and 552 Confederate. (American Battlefield Trust; National Park Service)

The Battle of Shiloh (also known as the Battle of Pittsburg Landing) was fought on April 6 – 7, 1862 in Hardin County, Tennessee between the Army of the Tennessee (Union) commanded by Maj. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant against the Army of Mississippi (Confederate) commanded by Gen. Sidney Albert Johnston, and later, by Gen. P.G.T. Beauregard. It resulted in a Union victory. After the fall of Forts Henry and Donelson in February of 1862, Johnston withdrew Confederate forces from Kentucky and central and western Tennessee, opening Mississippi and Alabama to attack from the Union Army. Johnston suspected that Grant would attack Corinth, Mississippi, the hub of the Ohio and Mobile and Memphis and Charleston railroads, an important Confederate supply route. He gathered his forces at Corinth and marched north to Pittsburgh Landing, Tennessee to attack Grant before Union reinforcements could arrive.

Fighting began on the morning of April 6. Initially, Johnston’s forces had the element of surprise, attacking Union soldiers at their camp and driving them back toward Pittsburgh Landing. Union forces regrouped and counter-attacked. That afternoon, Johnston was shot in his knee, the ball severing an artery and killing him from blood loss. Command fell to Beauregard who believed his forces were victorious and ordered the attack halted as darkness fell that evening. Grant, receiving reinforcements overnight, launched an attack on the morning of April 7. Beauregard counter-attacked, but the two sides reached a stalemate. That afternoon Beauregard realized that Grant was reinforced, and he was outnumbered. He retreated with his forces to Corinth. The total number of forces engaged in the battle was 110,053; 65,085 Union and 44,968 Confederate. Casualties from the battle were estimated at 23,746 with 13,047 Union and 10,669 Confederate. The Confederate defeat at Shiloh gave the Union access to several hundred miles of the Mississippi River to launch operations further into to South. Also of note, Sidney Albert Johnston would be the highest-ranking Confederate general killed in the war (American Battlefield Trust; Tennessee Encyclopedia; Encyclopedia Britannica)

Military elections were a common practice within volunteer and militia units of both the Union and Confederacy during the Civil War, a tradition with its roots going back to the Revolutionary War. These elections took place at the company and regimental levels. Company officers were elected by the unit’s soldiers, and in turn, these company officers elected the regiment’s Colonel, Lt. Colonel, and Majors. Officially, Governors had the authority to appoint a Colonel to command a regiment but usually deferred to the officer elected by the regiment's men. Often, these elections put men without military experience or otherwise unqualified to lead their units into battle with disastrous outcomes. Also, junior officers found it difficult to enforce military discipline as they were beholden to the soldiers for their position, which they could be voted out of.

Union and Confederate authorities sought to limit the detrimental effects of these officer elections. On July 22, 1861, the day after the Union loss at the First Battle of Bull Run, the United States Congress authorized an examination board for officers. Many were deemed unfit and removed, while others resigned. The Confederate Congress established a similar board on October 13, 1862. Military elections continued during the war but to a lesser extent due to government oversight on both sides. They eventually ended in favor of ensuring qualified officers were put in command positions. (James M. McPherson, Battle Cry of Freedom: The Civil War Era; Public Laws of the Confederate States of America, 1862 Public Laws, S2, 85-87; Wikipedia)

At the outbreak of the American Civil War in 1861, neither the Union nor the Confederate army struggled to find recruits. Rather, both armies saw far more volunteers than their ranks and provisions could sustain. Many young men of the North and South believed that the war would end quickly and volunteered by the thousands to not miss out on the action. Other motivators for rapid enlistment included a sense of adventure, defense of slavery or the privileges of whiteness, defense of the Union, fear of ostracism in their home communities for not enlisting, or a desire to protect their homes and families.

Widespread enlistment required both the United States and Confederate governments to reshape their militaries that were otherwise unprepared to handle that many recruits. The U.S. possessed only a small standing army of 16,000 men before the war, and the Confederacy needed to build its own from scratch. Both therefore relied heavily on local recruiting to organize men into militia companies then employable in the federal service. Recruiters throughout the war published pamphlets, put up posters, and gave speeches to encourage men to fight.

As the war continued, dreams of a short war ended along with many men's desires to enlist. Both armies (the Confederacy in 1862 and the Union in 1863) resorted to conscription to fill their ranks. Free African Americans, particularly in the North, debated the utility and wisdom of fighting for the United States even after being legally allowed to do so in 1863. Many formerly enslaved African-American men yearned to fight for their own freedom, while others doubted that military service in the Civil War would accomplish their desired goals of emancipation and equality. However, prominent African Americans such as Frederick Douglass encouraged Black men to take up arms, and roughly 200,000 did so.

Ultimately, men enlisted during the Civil War for many reasons, often tied to demographic or personal causes, and, as the war progressed and varied in its popularity and aims, recruiters' tactics likewise changed to adapt to each new situation. (Encyclopedia of Arkansas)

gloss.p: The Confederate Army was the military land force of the Confederate States of America during the American Civil War. Known also as the Confederate States Army or Southern Army, it was established by the Provisional Confederate Congress in February 1861 and fell under the authority of Confederate President Jefferson Davis. Modeled after the U.S. Army of the 19th century, the Confederate Army technically fell into two categories: a small regular army of professional officers and soldiers (the Army of the Confederate States of America) and a much larger, temporary force of citizen soldiers intended to exist only for the duration of the war (the Provisional Army of the Confederate States). In reality, the Confederacy’s regular army never fully developed and the overwhelming majority of Confederate soldiers served in the provisional force. The distinction between the two played little role during military operations and all were generally considered to be part of the overall Confederate Army.

As many as 1,000,000 soldiers served in the Confederate Army between 1861 and 1865, although not all at one time. Most were volunteers, however, the Confederate government instituted a conscription (or draft) in April 1862—the first in U.S. or Confederate history—to increase the size of the Confederacy’s military force and encourage voluntary enlistment. The government passed two more conscription acts over the next two years. More than ten percent of the men who served in Confederate ranks were drafted.

Over ninety percent of soldiers in the Confederate Army were native-born white men. Nine percent were foreign-born white men. Several Native American units—particularly from the Cherokee, Creek, and Choctaw tribes—served within the Confederate military, especially in the trans-Mississippi theatre. The Confederate military heavily relied upon the forced labor of enslaved African Americans for building fortifications and carrying out menial tasks, and the Confederate government did not formally allow African Americans (free or slave) to join the army until a last minute desperate measure passed the Confederate Congress in March 1865, only weeks before the end of the war. Only around two hundred enslaved soldiers were organized into service, but they were not sent into combat.

By the time the last Confederate soldiers surrendered to Union forces in June 1865, nearly 100,000 had been killed in combat or succumbed to wounds, more than 160,000 had died of disease, and roughly 30,000 had died in prison camps. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: The 15th Regiment, Mississippi Infantry (Confederate) was organized on May 21, 1861 in Alcorn County, Mississippi under the command of Col. Winfield S. Statham and served in the Western Theater under Zollicoffer's and Bowen's Brigades. It was later commanded by Col. Michael Farrell. It was reorganized in May 1862 and consolidated into the 15th Regiment, Mississippi Consolidated Infantry on April 9, 1865 under the command of Lt. Col. Thomas B. Graham. (Howell, Jr., Military History of Mississippi, 21; Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 614-620; National Park Service-Battle Units)

gloss.p: Commonly known as the Quitman Rifles, Company C of the 15th Regiment, Mississippi Infantry (Confederate) was organized on April 20, 1861 in Holmes County, Mississippi under the command of Capt. J. W. Wade and served in the Western Theater. It was later commanded by Capt. William Collins. (Howell, Jr., Military History of Mississippi, 21; Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 615)

div.p: It affords me pleasure to endorse Capt William, Collins the gentleman herein referred to, as a good soldier, a brave and gallant officer,
He was for twelve months Capt. of one of the best Companies in the Old 15th Missi Regt—was ever prompt energetic & efficient in the discharge of his duties—.

No man or officer in the Regt. Stood higher or won a more enviable name for true bravery and gallant bearing—I Saw him, in the bloody fight at Fishing Creek, as well as in several other Skirmishes—He was in the battles of Shilo, before Corinth, & at Vicksburg, besides many other fights of smaller importance.

Capt. Collins the bearer of this wishes authority to raise a Company for state service—He acted as Captain of one of the Companies of the gallant 15th Regiment & was in the battle of Fishing Creek, He was considered one of the best Captains in that Regiment—He was beaten for Maj on ReOrganization only Two votes—
I refer you to Capt C G Armstead for the qualifications of Capt Collins, who was with him in the 15th Regmt.

Yr Obt Sevt
M D Haynes
6th Febry 1863

Hon M, D, Haynes &
Capt C, G, Armistead
